A little education for you so you don't stay stupid. The FactsThe Clintons played a major role in recovery efforts in Haiti after the devastating earthquake in 2010. Former president Bill Clinton was the public face of U.S. efforts in Haiti through several recovery roles. He was the United Nations special envoy to Haiti, co-leader of the Clinton-Bush Haiti Fund (with former president George W. Bush) and co-chairman of the Interim Haiti Recovery Commission, a quasi-government planning body that approved hundreds of millions of dollars in U.S. government-funded recovery projects.The U.S. Agency for International Development supported the commissionâ€™s efforts, and Hillary Clinton led the U.S. response in Haiti as secretary of state. The Clinton Foundation raised more than $30 million for Haiti relief projects.There are hospital projects that have been delayed, but thereâ€™s no evidence that there were â€œhundreds of millions of dollarsâ€ù in foundation money promised to those efforts.For example, the USAID inspector general found delays in the $99 million reconstruction of medical facilities and medical supply warehouses through the Health Infrastructure Program. This program included the $82.3 million construction of the countryâ€™s key public hospital, the Hospital of the State University of Haiti in Port-au-Prince, one of the first projects that the Interim Haiti Recovery Commission approved. But the project is backed by money from the U.S. government, Haiti and France â€” not the Clinton Foundation.Thereâ€™s a lot of criticism lodged against the Clintons for their involvement with recovery efforts in Haiti. But Cohenâ€™s claim that Hillary Clinton raised hundreds of millions of dollars through the Clinton Foundation for a hospital that was never delivered is not credible.

A little education for you so you don't stay stupid unless it's to much to read for your brain. The FactsThe Clintons played a major role in recovery efforts in Haiti after the devastating earthquake in 2010. Former president Bill Clinton was the public face of U.S. efforts in Haiti through several recovery roles. He was the United Nations special envoy to Haiti, co-leader of the Clinton-Bush Haiti Fund (with former president George W. Bush) and co-chairman of the Interim Haiti Recovery Commission, a quasi-government planning body that approved hundreds of millions of dollars in U.S. government-funded recovery projects.The U.S. Agency for International Development supported the commissionâ€™s efforts, and Hillary Clinton led the U.S. response in Haiti as secretary of state. The Clinton Foundation raised more than $30 million for Haiti relief projects.There are hospital projects that have been delayed, but thereâ€™s no evidence that there were â€œhundreds of millions of dollarsâ€ù in foundation money promised to those efforts.For example, the USAID inspector general found delays in the $99 million reconstruction of medical facilities and medical supply warehouses through the Health Infrastructure Program. This program included the $82.3 million construction of the countryâ€™s key public hospital, the Hospital of the State University of Haiti in Port-au-Prince, one of the first projects that the Interim Haiti Recovery Commission approved. But the project is backed by money from the U.S. government, Haiti and France â€” not the Clinton Foundation.Thereâ€™s a lot of criticism lodged against the Clintons for their involvement with recovery efforts in Haiti. But Cohenâ€™s claim that Hillary Clinton raised hundreds of millions of dollars through the Clinton Foundation for a hospital that was never delivered is not credible.

I don't understand why people keep saying, "But Hillary!" What someone else did in the past, be it the Clintons or the Bushes or Nixon or whoever, doesn't excuse our current politicians from bad, immoral, or illegal behavior. What Trump said -- which he doesn't deny -- that certain countries are "shithole countries," damages the U.S.A. Because it not only offends those impoverished countries that we want to be able to work with to help them solve certain issues so fewer of their citizens are trying to illegally enter our country, it also has offended our first world allies which makes it harder for us to have a seat at the table and a voice in discussions about global issues (which affect our economy, our safety/national security, our foreign interests, etc.). You can be a Trump supporter and still point out things he's done wrong. You don't have to blindly accept or defend every word that comes out of his mouth. You can say, "I like him and think he's doing a good job, but this statement was inappropriate/unpresidential/dangerous/etc. And in fact when you defend bad behavior, from any politician, when you defend Trump calling these places shithole countries, you are emboldening him/them to deny wrongdoing and continue the behavior, which will further hurt the U.S.A. Because you are Trump's supporters, it is even more important that you call him out when he's damaging the country, because he does care about what you think, and you do have an obligation as citizens of this country to guide your elected representatives, including the president, to do the best for this country that they can.

Haitians fought for the independence of the United States !!In 1779, a ship leaving Saint-Marc headed for the United States with valiant soldiers from Haiti. They were known as volunteer hunters from Santo Domingo, and they were part of what is often called the siege of Savannah or the battle of Savannah.The D'Estaing Division included 156 Volunteer Grenadiers from Cape Francis, 545 Volunteer Fighters from St. Dominic, and these included troops from Port-au-Prince and Cape Town, as Cap Haitian was then known. D'Estaing would have had 3500 troops, whether the number of free blacks and mulattoes is 800 or 1500, historians differ.And the battle of Savannah was not the only battle in which Haitians were involved. The historian and journalist Ralph Pezzullo highlights another battle that took place at Lynnwood Harbor off Florida in 1781, in which the British commander Lord Cornwallis was defeated by a fleet of Santo Domingo (the French colonial name of Haiti) . Historians point out that the Battle of Savannah played a crucial role in the American struggle for the independence of England, and that it was one of the bloodiest battles.

Patricia Sohn In the past 35 days, Trump has averaged an astonishing nine claims a day.The total now stands at 1,628 claims in 298 days, or an average of 5.5 claims a day. That puts the president on track to reach 1,999 claims by the end of his first year in office, though he obviously would easily exceed 2,000 if he maintained the pace of the past month. (Our full interactive graphic can be found here.)As regular readers know, the president has a tendency to repeat himself â€” often. There are now at least 50 claims that he has repeated three or more times.Trumpâ€™s most repeated claim, uttered 60 times, was some variation of the statement that the Affordable Care Act is dying and â€œessentially dead.â€ù The Congressional Budget Office has said that the Obamacare exchanges, despite well-documented issues, are not imploding and are expected to remain stable for the foreseeable future. Indeed, healthy enrollment for the coming year has surprised health-care experts.Trump also repeatedly takes credit for events or business decisions that happened before he took the oath of office â€” or had even been elected. Fifty-five times, he has touted that he secured business investments and job announcements that had been previously announced and could easily be found with a Google search.But with the push in Congress to pass a tax plan, two of Trumpâ€™s favorite talking points about taxes â€” that the tax plan will be the biggest tax cut in U.S. history and that the United States is one of the highest-taxed nations â€” have been moving up the list.Trump repeated the falsehood about having the biggest tax cut 40 times, even though Treasury Department data shows it would only rank eighth. And 50 times Trump has claimed that the United States pays the highest corporate taxes (19 times) or that it is one of the highest-taxed nations (31 times). The latter is false; the former is misleading, as the effective U.S. corporate tax rate (what companies end up paying after deductions and benefits) ends up being lower than the statutory tax rate.We also track the presidentâ€™s flip-flops on our list, as they are so glaring. He spent the 2016 campaign telling supporters that the unemployment rate was really 42 percent and the official statistics were phony; now, on 33 occasions he has hailed the lowest unemployment rate in 17 years. It was already very low when he was elected â€” 4.6 percent, the lowest in a decade â€” so his failure to acknowledge that is misleading.Fifty-seven times, Trump has celebrated a rise in the stock market â€” even though in the campaign he repeatedly said it was a â€œbubbleâ€ù that was ready to crash as soon as the Federal Reserve started raising interest rates. Well, the Fed did raise rates three times since the election â€” and yet it has not plunged as Trump predicted. It has continued a rise in stock prices that began under Barack Obama in 2009.Again, the president has never explained his shift in position on the stock market. But he couldnâ€™t stop talking about it during his trip to Asia.We maintain the database by closely reading or watching Trumpâ€™s myriad public appearances and television and radio interviews. The interviews are especially hard to keep up with, in part because the White House does not routinely post on them on its website. Moreover, Trump tends to seek out right-leaning interviewers who rarely challenge him or question him when he repeats false claims that have already been fact-checked. The interviews thus often contain a torrent of misleading claims, and we despair that supposed journalists are not confronting the president about his rhetoric.So we were amused to see a foreign leader fact-check the president on his Asian trip. On Nov. 13, Trump met with Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe when he started to repeat one of his favorite false claims that the United States has â€œdeficits with almost everybody.â€ùâ€œExcept us,â€ù interjected Turnbull.â€œExcept with you,â€ù Trump agreed, adding: â€œYouâ€™re the only one.â€ù He then suggested he should check the figures, but Turnbull assured him, â€œItâ€™s real.â€ùIndeed, the United States has a goods trade surplus of $13 billion and services trade surpluses of $15 billion with Australia, largely because of a Free Trade Agreement, according to the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative.We assume Trump was joking when he said Australia was the â€œonly one.â€ù But for the record, the United States also has trade surpluses with the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Brazil, Belgium, Singapore, Hong Kong, Chile, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, among other countries, according to the International Trade Commission.(About our rating scale)Send us facts to check by filling out this formKeep tabs on Trumpâ€™s promises with our Trump Promise TrackerSign up for The Fact Checker weekly newsletter
